questions.question_text: A systems administrator has recently purchased and installed a large electronic signage screen for the company's parking garage. The screen's management software was installed on a server with a public IP address to allow remote management. The systems administrator is now troubleshooting an issue with the screen displaying unknown, random, and inappropriate messages. Which of the following is MOST effective in resolving this issue?

choices.B: Disabling unnecessary services from the server and management software
choices.A: Changing the management software's default credentials
choices.C: Changing the management software's default port
choices.D: Replacing the management software's self-signed certificate with a valid certificate

discussion.content: ridiculous question.

Think about it from a security standpoint. Which of these answers is going to be easiest for the hacker to take over the system? 
A) If it has default username and password guess how easy it is to get in -- cake. 
B) Disabling unnecessary services won't block a hacker from using the services that the management team will also need to use(thats why they gave it a public IP right?). 
C) Changing the port, but leaving the default username/password isn't going to stop anyone from getting into the system. It might confuse them for a brief second until they see the traffic on another port.
D) changing the certificate only protects the communications, it will not thwart a hacker from gaining admin access to the system.
Why can't it be B? Someone can break into the server and gain access to display inappropriate messages
sometimes you have to figure out like this kind of question.

If it only said "inappropriate messages" this would be much easier to understand that it was an malicious actor that had gained access. The oddness of the question shouldn't be an issue. This website is here to help you get used to different types of scenarios.

yes i agree ridiculous question but something like this was on one of Jason Dion's exam
Think about it if you have default credentials you can do anything to any device such take a picture of richard simmons and put it on your friends computer at work
doesnt make sense

comments.content: doesn't matter how much you study for a question like this, shit like this is intended to throw people off during the exam.

discussion.content: I agree

questions.question_text: A network technician wants to ensure the backup configuration files for the network devices are not being altered after they are stored. Which of the following tasks should the network technician perform to achieve this goal?

choices.B: Store the backup files on a thumb drive and keep it in a desk drawer.
choices.A: Compute the checksum of the backup file and document it separately.
choices.C: Encrypt the drive the files are stored on using AES-256.
choices.D: Upload the backup files to a cloud storage service.

discussion.content: CHECKSUM is part of a backup operation which will instruct SQL Server to test each page being backed up with its corresponding checksum, making sure that no corruption has occurred during the read/write process. If a bad checksum is found, the backup will fail
Really weird question tbh, C would be ideal

choices.C: Behind the firewall on the core switch
choices.A: In front of the modem and firewall

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is installing a new IDS device that will collect logs and alert the administrator of breaches.
* The network infrastructure includes a modern, a firewall, and core and access switches.
* The modem is ISP provided and only forwards packets from the data circuit.
* The firewall handles stateful packet inspection, the ACL, and application layer filtering.
Which of the following describes where the administrator should install the IDS device on the network to collect the MOST relevant information?

comments.content: Agreed. Unless I am misinterpreting this question. IDS generally sit behind a FW

"IDS device that will collect logs and alert the administrator of breaches"
It's especially best to have your IDS in front of your modem and even in front of your firewall so you are notified of breaches before they happen. The IDS does not prevent breaches, it detects them. Before a breach happens, you'd want to know about it to have time to react. The answer is correct.

discussion.content: I have never seen an IDS in front of the modem. I think this is wrong. An IDS is normally behind the firewall.

From Cisco website 
You can place an IDS appliance in front of or behind a firewall. Each position has its benefits and drawbacks. Placing an IDS appliance in front of a firewall allows the IDS appliance to monitor all incoming and outgoing network traffic. However, when deployed in this manner, the IDS appliance does not normally detect traffic that is internal to the network. An internal attacker taking advantage of vulnerabilities in network services would remain undetected by the external IDS appliance. Placing an IDS appliance (a monitoring or sniffing interface) behind a firewall shields the IDS appliance from any policy violations that the firewall rejects.

I'd go with C because per the Net+ Dion Training Jason guy, the IDS is run parallel to the network (connected to a switch) and the IPS operates in-line to the network (between firewall and switch). Since this is an IDS question, and as C mentions a switch that's also behind a firewall, I'd go with it.

A is wrong, IDS would never be in front of the modem. D is similarly wrong, it won't be able to monitor enough traffic. That leaves B and C, which both are viable in the real world. In this situation, the key phrase to pay attention to is "collect the most relevant information." If you place the IDS in front of the firewall, you'll get a lot of useless traffic and information which the firewall may block anyway. The question is concerned about BREACHES, so C is the correct answer.
If the goal is to detect breaches wouldnâ€™t it have to be on the inside of the firewall? If not what is being breached?

I dont believe putting it front of the modem is even physically possible. I have never seen a IDS behind a firewall either, however, the question states the firewall is using "stateful packet inspection" which may filter the traffic. So to gather the most info you may want to put it in front of the firewall. I am guessing B.
Man hopefully the question will be worded more concisely on test day...

Unfortunately, the question can be interpreted in two ways:
1. The person who is following him closely is already doing tailgaiting ... in other words, tailgating is in progress. So if the network administrator sent him to the security desk, he just stopped a tailgating ... so the answer might be B

2. Given that someone was following the admin, the next step would have been shoulder surfing which was stopped, meaning the answer D

So it depends on how the situation is interpreted, I can't figure out exactly.

comments.content: But the question tells us what exactly WAS PREVENTED, not STOPPED, so logically the answer would be D.
Right, rbe, and this is what would have resulted from the administrator being tailgated. The answer is looking for what was PREVENTED, not what has already happened.

tailgating is correct.

Shoulder surfing is when you steal data by spying over the shoulder, such as password or pin

discussion.content: I am not sure the answer is tailgating. the question implies the administrator has entered the data center and there is someone behind him. If I understand this, it means both are already in the data center, so tailgating would not have been prevented. I believe Shoulder Surfing should be the answer since he was following him.

comments.content: Piggybacking is a form of tailgating but you have the authorized users consent to follow them

What is an example of a piggybacking?
Piggybacking is defined as stealing, or commandeering, a wireless connection. An example of piggybacking is using your neighbor's connection. An illegal practice in which a broker mimics a client's trade.

discussion.content: Tailgating = Piggybacking

questions.question_text: A network administrator walks into a datacenter and notices an unknown person is following closely. The administrator stops and directs the person to the security desk. Which of the following attacks did the network administrator prevent?

Good luck everyone on your exam! Taking mine on the 26th, fingers crossed!
Thank you all. I will sit for the exam tomorrow :)

questions.question_text: A user has just received a call from someone claiming to be from the company help desk and asking for password information to assist the user with a password reset. Company policy, however, states the help desk will not ask for password information. Which of the following has the user just experienced?
